title: How Do I Create a Blog? (The Meta First Post)
text:
üìò Welcome to my blog ‚Äî a space where I‚Äôll be exploring ideas about teaching, physics, coding, and AI.

section: üîß How I Set Up This Blog
text:
üîß How I Set Up This Blog
Here‚Äôs a quick rundown of the steps I followed to get everything working:

Install Quarto
I downloaded and installed Quarto. It‚Äôs an open-source scientific and technical publishing system that integrates beautifully with VS Code.


Create a new Quarto project
In the VS Code terminal, I used the Quarto extension to create a new website project:
quarto create-project myblog --type website


Create structure and posts
Now comes the beauty of using Copilot Pro Agent: I just asked the agent to create the files, folders, modify the index.qmd, add my pictures, etc. Isntead of looking for the commands in google or asking chatgpt in a different window, I ask Copilot Agent in plain english. ### Preview the site locally I used:
quarto preview
This lets me see changes live in my browser as I edit.


Push to GitHub
I initialized a Git repo, committed everything, and pushed it to a new GitHub repository.


Enable GitHub Pages
In the GitHub repo settings, I enabled Pages and selected the main branch and /docs folder as the source.


Publish with Quarto
I rendered the site into the docs folder using:
quarto render
Now the site is live at: üëâ https://vladimirlopez.github.io/the-thinking-experiment

That‚Äôs it for now. This blog will be a thinking space ‚Äî a lab notebook, a course companion, and maybe a bit of a philosophical experiment. Thanks for reading the very first post.
Next up: What is vibe-coding, really?

title: The Thinking Experiment begins
text:
I‚Äôm a physics teacher with broad interests and a deep curiosity for how we learn, how we teach, and how we make sense of the world.
Over the years, I‚Äôve taught high school Math, Science, and Engineering. Lately, I‚Äôve been exploring how AI can support teaching, learning, and even thinking itself. I‚Äôm trying a lot of things ‚Äî in the classroom, in code, in my own workflows ‚Äî and this blog is a space to share what I discover.
But this isn‚Äôt just about physics or AI.
It‚Äôs about the bigger picture: how we grow as educators, how curiosity evolves over time, and how ideas from science, literature, philosophy, and everyday experience shape the way we see and explain the world.
The Thinking Experiment is part lab notebook, part essay collection, part journal of the unexpected. I hope you‚Äôll find something here that makes you think ‚Äî or re-think ‚Äî along the way.
Let the experiment begin.
